stem: Situation: A block of copper having a mass of 50 kg is drawn out to make 500m of wire of uniform cross-section. Given that the density of copper is 8.91 g/cm³, calculate the following: What is the volume of steel in cubic centimeter?
What is the cross-sectional area of the wire in square millimeters?
What is the diameter of the wire in mm?
Situation: Two conic sections have the following equations: x² + y² - 8x + 4y - 16 = 0 and y² - 16x + 4y + 68 = 0. Which of the following defines these conics?
Which of the following is a point of intersection of the conics?
What is the distance between their points of intersection?
Situation: Solve the following geometry problems. A sphere of radius 6 units have its center at the origin. Which of the following points is outside the sphere?
A sphere of radius 15 units have its center at the origin. Given three points P₁(6, 8, 9), P₂(5, 8, 10), and P₃(4, 3, 12). Which of the following is/are inside the sphere?
Find the distance of the following points in three-dimensional space: (0, 0, 0) and (5, 6, 7).
Situation: Solve the following solid geometry problems: A cylinder is inscribed in a cube of side 2 meters. Find the volume inside the cube but outside the cylinder.
Given a cube of side 1 m. Find the volume of the cone inscribed in this cube, with base of cone on one side of the cube.
The sides of a rectangular parallelepiped measure 3 cm, 4 cm, and 6 cm. Find the radius of the sphere that can circumscribe this solid.

Situation: Answer the following algebra problems: In a company of CE, ME, and EE, the sum of all their ages is 2160 and their average age is 36. The average age of CE and ME is 39, of CE and EE is 110/3, and of EE and ME is 360/11. If the ages of CE is increased by 1, of ME is increased by 6, and of EE is increased by 7, the average of all their ages in increased by 5. How many CE are there?

Engineer Cruz started walking from point O at uniform speed of 6 kph. After 2 hours, Engineer Fernandez started walking from the same point O and walked 4 km in the first hour, 5 km in the second hour, and so on, increasing 1 km each hour. How many hours after Engr. Cruz left point O will they be together?

A farmer owns two square lots of unequal size, together containing 6,568 m². If the lots are contiguous, it would require 356 m of fence to enclose them into a single enclosure of six sides. What is the dimension of the smaller lot?

Situation: Answer the following calculus problems: A triangle in the first quadrant is bounded by the X- and Y- axes and a line that passes through (1, 2). What is the slope of the line if the area of the triangle is to be minimum?
What is the nearest distance from the hyperbola x² - y² = 4 to point (6, 0)?

An inverted conical tank has a base radius of 10 m and height of 20 m. Water flows out from the tank at 150 liters per second. How fast is the water surface falling when the depth of water in the tank is 8 m?

Situation: A square lot 1 kilometer on each side is divided into five equal parts. The parts consist of four equal right triangles and a square at the center of the lot. What is the dimension of the smaller square in meters?
If this process is continued, what will be the dimension of the next smaller square in meters?
What is the ratio of the area of the smallest square to the original square?

Situation: Two trains A and B are travelling in the same direction, with train A behind train B. Train A, 65 meters long, is travelling at 240 kph. Train B, 85 meters long, is travelling at 120 kph. At a certain instant, the trains are 200 m apart (clear distance). Find the time when train A starts to overtake train B.
Find the time when train A completely overtakes Train B.
Find the distance travelled by train A when it completely overtakes train B.
Situation: In a certain barangay, 80% of the population have cellphone. Two people from the barangay were selected at random. Find the probability that the two have cellphones.
Find the probability that one has cellphone and the other has none.
Find the probability that the two have no cellphones.
Situation: Evaluate the following limits: Lim (4x² + 19x - 30) / (4x² - 33x + 35) as x approaches 1.25.
Lim (2x³ - 6x² - 8x + 24) / (x² - 2x - 3) as x approaches 3.
Lim (x³ + 8x² + x - 42) / (x² + 10x + 21) as x approaches -3.
Situation: The probability of event A happening is 3/5 and the probability of event B happening is 2/3. Calculate the following: What is the probability of both A and B happening?
What is the probability of only event A happening, i.e. event A happening and event B not happening.
What is the probability of either A, or B, or A and B happening.

Situation: Six congruent circles are arranged in circle in a way that each circle is tangent to at least two other circles. If the radius of each circle is 2 cm, find the perimeter of the polygon formed by connecting the centers of each circles. What is the perimeter?
Which of the following is/are correct: I. sin(-A) = -sin(A), II. cos(-A) = -cos(A), III. tan(-A) = -tan(A)?
A solid rectangular block has a volume of 30 cm³. If all side measure are integers, which of the following is the least possible surface area?
Situation: Answer the following problems: What is the distance between the intercepts of the line x + 2y - 6 = 0?
If |x² - 3| ≤ 5, find the range of values of x.
For the function f(x) = |x| + 10, what are the values of x where f(x) = f(-x)?
Situation:A particle moves according to the equation: S = t⁴ + 6t³ - 12t² + C. Where t is in seconds and S in meters. What is the time t when the particle is at rest?
What is the time t (range) when the particle's speed is increasing?
What is the time t (range) when the particle's speed is decreasing?
Situation– Answer the following problems: If the radius of a sphere is increasing at a constant rate, what is the rate of change of the volume?
A sedimentation tank has a regular pentagonal base with area of 150 m² and height of 7 m. What is the volume of the tank?
The volume of a cube is 512 cubic centimeters. What is the measure of the side of the cube in cm?
Situation  – Answer the following problems:  If y varies inversely as z and y = 23 when z = 45,000, find y when z = 54,000.

From a window of a building 4.25 m above the ground, the angle of elevation of the top of a nearby building is 36.6° and the angle of depression of its base is 26.2°. What is the height of the nearby building?

From a point A [El. 000], the angle of elevation of the top of a tower is 32°. From a point B 321 m nearer the tower and 19.65 m below point A, the angle of elevation of the top of the tower is 55°. What is the elevation of the top of the tower?
Situation  – A frustum of a sphere is 6.6 cm thick. The diameters of its upper and lower bases are 18.5 cm and 32.9 cm, respectively. What is the radius of the sphere in cm?
What is the volume of the frustum in cm³?
What is the lateral surface area of the frustum, in cm²?

Situation– Two trains A & B are moving on parallel tracks in the same direction and at different speeds. Train B, 100 m long, is moving at 100 kph. Train A, 150 m long, is behind train B and moving at 250 kph. At a certain instant, the head of train A is 800 m behind the tail of train B. How long will it take for the head of train A to reach the tail of train B?
How long will it take for the head of train A to reach the head of train B?
How long will it take for the train A to completely overtake train B?
Situation – Given the following curves: Curve 1: y = x² + 7x + 6  Curve 2: x - 2y = 6. What are the points of intersection of the two curves?
What are the slopes of curve 1 at points of intersection?
Which of the following statements defines the two curves?
Situation – Answer the following problems. What is the area bounded by the curves y = 2/x and the line y = 3 - x.
Point of intersection, above x-axis, between the curves y = sin x and y = cos x.
What is the area bounded by the curves y = sin x and y = cos x from π/4 to 5π/4?
X and Y are inversely proportional with each other. Given that X = 15,000 when Y = 162,500. Find X when Y = 328,400.
The sum of seven consecutive integers is zero. What is the smallest integer?
The sum and product of three distinct positive integers are 15 and 45, respectively. What is the largest integer?
What is the curved surface area of a spherical segment (with two bases) if the diameters of the bases, which are 25 cm apart, are 100 cm and 140 cm, respectively?
The area of a park on a map is 500 mm². If the scale of the map is 1 to 40,000 determine the true area of the park in hectares (1 hectare = 10^4 m²).
Evaluate the integral: ∫ from π/3 to 2π/3 of cscx cotx dx.
Find the general solution of the following differential equation: y'' + 3y' - 4y = 0.
choices: y = C1 e^(4x) + C2 x e^(-x)
y = C1 e^(-4x) + C2 x e^x

stem: Situation – Ohm's law states that the current flowing in a fixed resistor is directly proportional to the applied voltage. When 30 volts is applied across a resistor the current flowing through the resistor is 2.4 x 10^-3 amperes. Determine the following: The constant of proportionality.
The current when the voltage is 52 volts.
The voltage when the current is 3.6 x 10^-3 amperes.

Situation – Charles's law states that for a given mass of gas at constant pressure the volume is directly proportional to its thermodynamic temperature. A gas occupies a volume of 2.25 liters at 300°K. Determine the following: The constant of proportionality,
The volume at 420°K
The temperature when the volume is 2.625 liters.
Situation – Answer the following problems: If f(x) = x^5 - 2x^2 + 3/x, then f(-1) is equal to:
If the absolute value of x is greater than the absolute value of y, which of the following is always true?
If abc - de is positive, which of the following is always correct?
Situation – Answer the following problems: What is the value of x - y from the following linear equations? 3x - 5y = 14,  6x - 3y = 21
Solve for x if 48^x = 4 × 3^x
Given the following equations: a × b = 1/8, a × c = 3, b × c = 6. Find the product of a, b, and c.
Situation – Answer the following problems: If xyz = 8 and y²z = 12, what is the value of x/y?
Find the non-zero solution to the equation 3x⁴ - 30x³ = 0.
A line is divided into 10 equal parts. If the measure of each part is a prime integer, what is the possible length of the line?
Situation – Answer the following problems: Mario’s hat is four more than Alex’s hat and one-half that of Miguel’s hat. If the total number of hats is 24, how many hats does Miguel have?
The shipment of items is divided into two portions. If the difference between the portions is half of their average, what is the ratio of the larger portion to the smaller portion?
A group of musicians is composed of three drummers, four pianists, and five guitarists. How many ways can a trio be formed with 1 pianist, 1 drummer, and 1 guitarist?
Situation – Answer the following rate problems: If a car can travel "x" km in "y" hours, how many hours can it travel a distance of "z" km?
If 8 men can cut 28 trees in a day, how many trees can 20 men cut in a day?
Kim can do a work in 1 hour, Ken can do it in 2 hours, and Karla can do it in 3 hours. Working together from start, how long can they do the work?
Situation – A train takes four hours and thirty minutes to travel from station A to station B. How long will the journey be if: The train’s speed is increased to 1.5 times its original speed.
The train’s speed is increased to 3.75 times its original speed.
The train’s speed is decreased to 0.75 times its original speed.

Situation – Two trains A & B are moving on parallel tracks in the same direction and at different speeds. Train B, 180 m long, is moving at 120 kph. Train A, 120 m long, is behind train B and moving at 180 kph. At a certain time, the clear distance between the trains is 550 m. Find the distance travelled by train B when the front end of train A caught up with its tail end?
Find the distance travelled by train A when its front caught up with the tail end of train B?
How long will it take for train A to completely overtake train B?
Situation – Answer the following sequence problems: What is the 12th term of the sequence: 5, 10, 20, ...
Find the sum of the first 10 terms of the following sequence: 0.25, 0.75, 2.25, ...
The fourth term of a geometric progression is 1.5 and the 8th term is 24. What is the 14th term?
Situation – A manufacturer estimates that 1.5% of his output of a small item is defective. Find the probabilities that in a pack of 200 items: None is defective.
Two are defective.
Three or more are defective.

Situation – Answer the following statistics problems: Suppose that the amount of time a passenger spends in paying a terminal fee is exponentially distributed with mean 20 seconds. What is the probability that a passenger will spend more than 25 seconds in the booth?

Studies of a machine component showed that the time the component operates before breaking down is exponentially distributed with a mean of 1000 hours. Calculate the maximum operating hours if the reliability is to be above 99%.

At a certain stretch of highway, the speeds of vehicles were found to have a normal distribution with a mean of 54 kph and a standard deviation of 3 on a sample of 25 vehicles. What is the upper two-standard deviation average speed?
Situation – Which of the following is equivalent to the given trigonometric expressions? (csc x)(cot x)
(1/sin x)(cot x)
Which of the following is equivalent to sec²x - 1?

Situation – Answer the following trigonometry problems: From a window of a building 3.2 m above the ground, the angle of elevation of the top of a nearby tower is 62.6° and the angle of depression of its base is 5.4°. What is the height of the nearby tower?

Two stations A and B were setup to determine the height of a mountain. The angle of elevation to the top of the mountain measured from stations A and B are 25.25° and 31.85°, respectively. Station A is 55 m above station B. Station B is 310 m closer to the mountain. If the elevation of station A is 650.15 m, what is the elevation of the top of the mountain?

In order to measure the height of a flagpole, an instrument is setup at A and the angle of elevation to the top of the flagpole was measured as 27.5°. The instrument is then setup at B, which is 56.3 m closer to the flagpole and on the same vertical plane as point A and the flagpole, and measured the angle of elevation as 62.3°. What is the height of the flagpole?

Situation – Answer the following trigonometry problems: An observer finds the angle of elevation of a building from X on a level ground as 27°. After moving 120 m closer to the building, the angle of elevation was 42°. Find the height of the building.

Two flies flew at the same time from the same point in different directions. One fly flew at 0.7 m/s and the other fly at 0.5 m/s. If the angle between their paths is 85°, find their distance after 2.5 seconds.
The sides of a triangular lot are 28.45 m, 47.12 m, and 35.64 m. What is the angle opposite the 42.12 m side?
Situation – In triangle ABC, side AB is 54 cm, side AC is 78 cm, and angle A is 56°. What is the measure of side BC?
What is the measure of angle B?
What is the measure of angle C?
Situation – The angle subtended by an arc of a circle of radius 60 cm is 152°. What is the length of the minor arc?
What is the length of the major arc?
What is the area of the bigger sector?

Situation – Answer the following plane geometry problems: The side of a regular pentagon is 32.2 cm long. Find the area between the circles inscribed in the hexagon and the circle circumscribed about the pentagon.
What is the ratio of area of circle to its radius?
How many circles of radius 4 cm can be cut from a rectangular sheet measuring 16 cm × 24 cm?

Situation – Answer the following plane geometry problems: An elliptical lot has a major axis of 300 m and a minor axis of 250 m. If the cost of fencing the is P1,500 per meter, what is the total cost of fencing the lot?

A race track is formed by two concentric ellipses. The outer ellipse has a major axis of 270 m and minor axis of 170 m. The inner ellipse has a major axis of 250 m and minor axis of 150 m. Find the area of the track.

The scale of an Ordinance Survey map is 1:2500. A circular sports field has a diameter of 8 cm on the map. Calculate its area in hectares, giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures. (1 hectare=10⁴ m²)
Situation – Answer the following solid geometry problems: A 6-m long steel pipe has an outside diameter of 12 cm and an inside diameter of 10 cm. Find the volume of steel in the pipe.

A square pyramid has base width of 4 m and height of 10 m. A smaller pyramid is cut from this pyramid by passing a plane 6 m from the base of the given pyramid. What is the volume of the small pyramid?
What is the curved surface area of a cone with base diameter of 80 cm and altitude of 150 cm?
Situation – Answer the following solid geometry problems: What is the volume of a cone with base diameter of 80 cm and altitude of 150 cm?

A loudspeaker diaphragm is in the form of a frustum of a cone. If the end diameters are 28.0 cm and 6.00 cm and the vertical distance between the ends is 30.0 cm, find the area of material needed to cover the curved surface of the speaker.

A rectangular prism of metal having dimensions 4.3 cm by 7.2 cm by 12.4 cm is melted down and recast into a frustum of a square pyramid, 10% of the metal being lost in the process. If the ends of the frustum are squares of side 3 cm and 8 cm respectively, find the thickness of the frustum.

Situation – Answer the following solid geometry problems: A cylindrical water tank is 2 m in diameter and 4 m high. This tank is to be replaced with another tank of the same capacity in the shape of a frustum of a cone with lower base diameter of 2 m and upper base diameter of 1.4 m. What height of tank is required?

A metal sphere weighing 24 kg is melted down and recast into a solid cone of base radius 8.0 cm. If the density of the metal is 8000 kg/m³ determine the height of the metal cone, assuming that 15% of the metal is lost in the process.

A model of a boiler is made having an overall height of 75 mm corresponding to an overall height of the actual boiler of 6 m. If the area of metal required for the model is 12,500 mm² determine, in square metres, the area for metal required for the actual boiler.

Situation – Answer the following solid geometry problems: A pressure tank is made of a cylinder of diameter 2 meters and height of 6 m, and two hemispheres mounted on each end of the cylinder. What is the volume of the tank?
The diameters of two spherical balls are in the ratio 3:4. What is the ratio of their volumes?
A spherical sector has a radius of 60 cm and an angle of 30°. What is the volume?
Situation – The frustum of a sphere is 3.8 cm thick. The diameters of its bases are 13.2 cm and 20.5 cm. Determine the following: The volume of the frustum.
The radius of the sphere.
The surface area of the zone.

Situation – A sphere of radius 20 cm is cut by two horizontal planes. One plane is 8 cm below the center of the sphere and the other is 14 cm above the center of the sphere. Determine the following: The radius of the lower base.
The radius of the upper base.
The volume of the frustum formed between the cutting planes.
Situation – Answer the following analytic geometry problems: What is the slope-intercept for of the line 3x - 2y + 8 = 0?
The function f(x) = (2x² + 6x - 9)/(x² - x - 2) will have vertical asymptote at:
Which of the following curves has twice the amplitude but half the period than the curve y = sin x?
Situation – Answer the following calculus problems: Evaluate the following limit: lim (x→0) (5x² + 3cosx - 3) / (2x)
If f(x) = x(2^x), then f'(x) is equal to:
A body moves according to the equation x(t) = (1 - t²) / (3 + t). What is the velocity of the particle when t = 1?
Situation – A conical tank 1 m diameter on top and 2 m deep is filled with water. Find the volume of water in the tank.
Find the weight of water in the tank if the unit weight of water is 9.81 kN/m³.
Find the work required to empty the full contents to the top of the tank.

Situation – A tank contains 100 liters of brine holding 60 kg of salt in solution. Water containing 1 kg of salt per liter flows into the tank at the rate of 2 liters/min, and the mixture, kept uniform by stirring, flows out at the rate of 3 liters/min. What is the initial concentration of salt in the solution in kg/liter?
What is the volume of the solution in the tank after 1 hour?
Find the amount of salt at the end of 1 hr.

Situation: A prestressed concrete pile, 360 mm × 360 mm in cross-section, is to be driven in a clayey soil (γ = 18.5 kN/m³) as shown in Figure 56-13(02)-S22. The pile has a design capacity of 360 kN. Use factor of safety of 2. The unconfined compression shear strength, qᵤ, of the soil is 110 kPa. Use Nc = 9. What is the end bearing capacity of pile in kN?
Compute the skin friction in kN expected to develop along the shaft of the pile.
Compute the length of the pile if frictional constant α = 0.75.

Situation: A confined aquifer is shown in Figure 36-56(78)S03. This aquifer has a source of recharge located as shown. The hydraulic conductivity of the aquifer is 45 m/day with a porosity of 25%. The piezometric (head) surface in the two observation wells 1650 m apart are at elevation 65 m and 60 m, respectively from the common datum. The aquifer has an average thickness of 25 m and an average width of 4 km. Determine the nearest value to the rate of flow of water through the aquifer, in cubic meters per day.
Determine the nearest value to the seepage velocity in m/day.
Determine the nearest value to the time of travel from the head of aquifer to a point 4.2 km downstream, in days.

Situation: A rectangular canal is 5.6 meters wide and 1.2 meters depth. The canal is laid on a uniform slope of 0.002 and roughness coefficient is 0.013. Calculate the discharge in the canal, in m³/s.
What savings in lining per meter length of canal could have been effected if the most efficient rectangular section were used for the same discharge and slope?
What savings in earth excavation per meter length of canal could have been effected if the most efficient rectangular section were used for the same discharge and slope?

Situation: A pump draws 24 liters per second of water from reservoir C and lifts it to reservoir D as shown in Figure 402. The head lost from C to 1 is 3 times the velocity head in the 150-mm suction line and the head lost from 2 to D is 25 times the velocity head in the 100-mm discharge line. What is the power delivered by the pump to the system in hp?
What is the pressure head at point 1 in meters of water?
What is the pressure head at point 2 in meters of water?

Situation: The result of a triaxial test on a cohesive soil is as follows: Angle of shearing resistance = 29°, Cohesion = 31 kPa, Maximum shearing stress = 65 kPa. Compute for the value of the cell pressure at failure, in kPa.
Compute for the value of the maximum principal stress at failure, in kPa.
Compute for the value of the normal stress at the plane of maximum shear, in kPa.
Situation: A closed conical tank has a bottom radius of 33 cm and is 50 cm tall. The tank contains 0.026 m³ of water. What is the depth of water in the tank in centimeters?
What is the total volume of the tank in cubic meter?
How much water is required to fill the tank, in cubic meters?

Situation: Water is flowing in a 200-mm-diameter rigid pipe that is 850 m long. The increase in pressure caused by instantaneous closure of the valve near the exit is 700 kPa. Bulk modulus of elasticity of water is 2.07 × 10⁹ Pa. What is the celerity of pressure wave in m/s?
What is the maximum discharge in m³/s?
What water hammer pressure is expected if the valve is closed in 3 seconds?
Situation: A tank 12 m high is to be filled with oil with unit weight of 9.4 kN/m³ as shown in Figure 2345. Neglect the weight of tank. Calculate the compression index of the clay layer.
Calculate the settlement under the center of the tank in mm.
Calculate the minimum depth to which the tank's base must be placed to minimize settlement.
Situation: Given the following properties of a soil: Specific gravity of solids = 2.70, Void ratio = 73%, Degree of saturation = 92%. Determine the nearest value to the moisture content of the soil.
Determine the nearest value to the dry unit weight of the soil.
Determine the nearest value to the moisture content when the soil is saturated.

Situation: A thick layer of saturated clay has moisture content of 59%. The specific gravity of soil solids is 2.68. The water table is on the ground surface. What is the density of clay in grams per cc?
What is the effective stress at a depth of 30 m?
What is the total stress at a depth of 30 m?

Situation – A cylindrical tank, 1 m in diameter and 2 m high weighs 1900 Newtons. The tank is to float in water with a draft of 1.7 m. Unit weight of lead is 110 kN/m³. How much lead is required if it is to be placed inside the tank?
How much lead is required if it is to be attached at the outside bottom of the tank?
In part 2, how much additional weight of lead is required to make the cylinder fully submerged in water?

Situation – A confined aquifer is shown in the Figure. This aquifer has a source of recharge located as shown. The hydraulic conductivity of the aquifer is 45 m/day with a porosity of 25%. The piezometric (head) surface in the two observation wells 1000 m apart are at elevation 65 m and 60 m, respectively from the common datum. The aquifer has an average thickness of 25 m and an average width of 4 km. Determine the nearest value to the rate of flow of water through the aquifer, in cubic meters per day.
Determine the nearest value to the seepage velocity in m/day.
Determine the nearest value to the time of travel from the head of aquifer to a point 4.2 km downstream, in days.
Situation – A certain liquid flows in a 10-mm-diameter smooth pipe that is 20 m long. The total head lost in the pipe is 30 m and the Reynolds number is 1800. What is the friction factor f?
What is the value of the kinematic viscosity of the liquid in m²/s?
What is the discharge in liters per minute?

Situation – The results of triaxial test on a cohesive soil is as follows: Maximum axial stress, σ₁ = 220 kPa, Deviator stress, σd = 140 kPa, Angle of shearing resistance, φ = 21°. Compute for the value of the confining pressure in kPa.
What is the cohesion of the soil in kPa?
What is the shearing stress at failure plane, in kPa?

Situation – Reservoir B in the Figure supplies 560 liters per second to reservoirs A and C. For this problem, the following data are given: Pipe 1: D = 600 mm, L = 500 m, Pipe 2: D = 800 mm, L = 800 m, Pipe 3: D = 400 mm, L = 800 m. Assume f = 0.025 for all pipes. What is the flow in pipe 1 in L/s?
What is the flow in pipe 3 in L/s?
What is the elevation of reservoir B in meters?

Situation – The water table in a soil layer is 1.5 meters below the ground. The soil above the water table is also saturated. Saturated unit weight of soil is 20.3 kN/m³. Determine the total pressure at plane A in kPa. (A is 4 meters below the ground).
Determine the pore water pressure at plane A, in kPa.
Determine the effective pressure at plane A, in kPa.

Situation – The square footing shown in Figure 003 carries a load of 3500 kN. Assume that the stress below the footing is distributed at a slope of 1H:2V. The clay layer is overconsolidated with OCR = 2. Determine the effective stress at the midheight of the clay layer, in kPa.
Determine the increase in pressure at the midheight of the clay layer, in kPa.
Determine the settlement of the overconsolidated clay layer, in mm.

Situation – Water is flowing in a 200-mm-diameter rigid pipe that is 850 m long, at the rate of 0.25 m/s. The valve near the exit end of the pipe was closed in 0.5 seconds. Bulk modulus of elasticity of water is 2.07 x 10^9 Pa. What is the celerity of pressure wave in m/s?
What is the water hammer pressure due to instantaneous closure, in kPa?
What is the maximum closure time that can be considered as instantaneous closure, in seconds?

Situation – A group of friction piles is shown in the Figure. The total load on the pile less the soil displaced by the footing is 1900 kN. L₁ = 1.2 m, L₂ = 1.2 m, L = 9 m, t = 17 m, qᵤ = 180 kPa, FS = 3. Compute for the overburden pressure, that is the effective pressure at the midheight of the consolidating clay layer, in kPa.
Compute for the compression index of the clay.
What is the approximate settlement of the foundation?
Situation – Given the laboratory results of the Atterberg Limits Test in Figure 004. Plot the water content versus the number of blows. Determine the nearest value to the Liquid Limit of the soil.
Determine the nearest value to the Plastic Limit of the soil.
Determine the nearest value to the Liquidity Index of the soil.
In laboratory test of determining the maximum dry density of a soil, if the compaction pressure is increased, the maximum dry density will:
When water table rises, what is its effect on effective stress?
The dry unit weight of a soil sample is 14.5 kN/m³. What is its saturated unit weight of the soil if Gs = 2.72?
The dry unit weight of a soil sample is 15 kN/m³. What is its buoyant unit weight of the soil if Gs = 2.58?

A constant head permeability test is conducted on a certain soil. The diameter of the sample is 5.5 cm, the length is 18 cm, and the constant head is 45 cm. The mass of water collected in 50 seconds is 80 grams. Determine the coefficient of permeability in cm/min.

Given the results of a constant-head permeability of a sand sample: Sample diameter = 250 mm, Length of sample = 250 mm, Constant head = 50 cm, Weight of water collected in 90 sec = 410 grams. Determine the coefficient of permeability in cm/min.

Given the following data for a falling-head permeability test of a soil. Diameter of soil = 80 mm, Length of soil sample = 150 mm, Area of tube = 0.018 cm², Time of observation, t = 65 sec, Initial head = 70 cm, Head after 65 seconds = 45 cm, Temperature = 14°C, μ14 = 0.01167 poise, μ20 = 0.01003 poise. Use the following formula: kT = k20 * (μT / μ20), where kT and μT are the permeability and absolute viscosity at temperature "T" and k20 and μ20 are the permeability and absolute viscosity at 20°C. Determine the coefficient of permeability at 20°C.

Situation – A sample of soil taken in the field has the following data: Unit weight of soil solids = 26.7 kN/m³, Void ratio = 67%, Moisture content = 20%. What is the degree of saturation of the soil?
Determine the saturated unit weight of the soil.
Determine the saturating moisture content.

Situation – Dry soil is mixed with 19% by weight with water and then compacted. The moist soil has a volume of 1 × 10⁻³ m³ and a mass of 1.6 kg. The soil solids have specific gravity of 2.72. What is the dry unit weight of the soil?
What is the void ratio of the soil?
What is the degree of saturation of the soil?

Situation – The results of field unit weight determination of a soil sample using the sand cone method is as follows: Volume of soil = 0.00134 m³, Mass of soil = 2250 grams, Dry mass of soil = 1734 grams. In a laboratory, this soil yields a dry density of 1.425 g/cc at optimum moisture content of 13.8%. What is the field unit weight of soil?
What is the in situ water content of soil?
Determine the relative compaction of the soil.

Situation – The result of sieve analysis of three soils is given next. It is required to classify these soils according to the AASHTO Classification System. Use the attached AASHTO. What is the classification of soil A?
What is the classification of soil B?
What is the classification of soil C?
Situation – Data from Atterberg limits test are provided. What is the liquid limit of the soil? (closest value)
What is the plastic limit of the soil? (closest value)
What is the liquidity index of the soil? (closest value)
Situation – The liquid and plastic limits of clay are 72% and 38%, respectively. Which of the following represents these percentages?
What is the plasticity index of this clay?
If the moisture content of this clay is 15%, what is its liquidity index?

Situation – A confined aquifer underlies an unconfined aquifer as shown in the figure. Given the following: D1 = 55 m, D2 = 40 m, H1 = 35 m, H2 = 30 m, K1 = 30 m/day, K2 = 40 m/day, L = 2 km. Calculate the equivalent coefficient of permeability in horizontal direction.
Calculate the hydraulic gradient.
Calculate the flow of water from one stream to another per meter width.

Situation – A 5.3 m thick of soil consist of three different layers as follows: Layer 1: H1 = 1.6 m, k1 = 4.5 m/day, Layer 2: H2 = 2.3 m, k2 = 3.5 m/day, Layer 3: H3 = 1.4 m, k3 = 5.1 m/day. What is the equivalent coefficient of permeability in the horizontal direction?
What is the transmissivity of the soil?
What is the seepage velocity assuming i = 0.005 and n = 35%?

Situation – The water table in soil deposit is 1 m below the ground surface. The soil above the water table has dry unit weight of 15.6 kN/m^3. The saturated unit weight of the soil is 18.6 kN/m^3. Determine the following: The total vertical stress at a point 4 m below the ground.
The total pore water pressure at a point 4 m below the ground.
The effective vertical stress at a point 4 m below the ground.

Situation – A 6 m thick homogeneous soil layer has dry unit weight of 16.1 kN/m^3 and saturated unit weight of 17.8 kN/m^3. The water table is located 4 m below the ground surface. What is the effective stress at the bottom of the layer?
What is the effective stress at the bottom of the layer if the water table goes up by 3 m?
Which of the following statements is correct when the water table rises to the ground surface?
choices: the effective pressure at the bottom of the layer will increase
the effective pressure at the bottom of the layer will remain the same
the effective pressure at the bottom of the layer will decrease
none of these statements is correct

stem: Situation – The water table in a 6-m thick clay layer is at the ground surface. The specific gravity of soil solids is 2.72 and the moisture content is 43%. What is the saturated unit weight of the clay?
What is the total stress at the bottom of the clay layer?
What is the effective stress at the bottom of the clay layer?

Situation – A borehole log profile in a construction project is shown in the figure. The proposed construction will impart a net stress of 12 N/cm^2. Use unit weight of water equal to 9.81 kN/m^3. Determine the nearest value to the buoyant unit weight of the clay.
Determine the nearest value to the effective vertical stress at the mid-height of the clay layer.
What is the average settlement of the normally consolidated clay layer in centimeters. Compression index Cc = 0.009(LL - 10).

Situation – A group of friction piles is shown in Figure 28.87 SM-57. The total load on the pile less the soil displaced by the footing is 1800 kN. L1 = 2 m, L2 = 1.8 m, L = 10 m, t = 17 m, qu = 180 kPa, FS = 3. Compute for the overburden pressure at the midheight of the consolidating clay layer, in kPa.
Compute for the compression index of the clay.
What is the approximate settlement of the foundation?

Situation – A sample of soil is subjected to a triaxial test. At a confining pressure of 60 kPa, the soil fails when the plunger exerts a pressure of 80 kPa. The plane of failure of the soil is 53°. Determine the following: The cohesion of the soil.
The normal stress at the plane of failure.
The shearing stress at the plane of failure.

Situation – In a triaxial test of a cohesionless soil, the normal and shearing stresses at failure plane are 500 kPa and 310 kPa, respectively. Determine the angle of shearing resistance of the soil in degrees.
Determine the angle of failure plane in degrees.
What is the principal stress at failure, in kPa?

Situation – A cantilever sheet-pile 7.5 m long supports a 4.5-m high dry sand with dry density of 1.19 g/cc and angle of shearing resistance of 34°. The pile is embedded to a depth of 3 m. The water table is at the bottom of the sheet pile. What is the maximum active force that can act on the sheet-pile per meter length?
What is the maximum passive resistance that can act on the sheet-pile per meter length?
What passive resistance must be mobilized for stability, per meter length?

Situation – The pile group shown consist of 12 piles, each 0.36 m in diameter arranged in a 3 × 4 matrix. The pile penetrates a soft clay (L1 = 3 m, cu1 = 56 kPa), a medium dense clay (L2 = 5 m, cu2 = 78 kPa), and a stiff clay (L3 = 4 m, cu3 = 95 kPa). Assume Nc = 9 and use α = 1 for soft and medium dense clay, α = 0.9 for stiff clay. Use FS = 3. Determine the capacity of the pile group based on single pile failure mode.
Determine the capacity of the pile group based on group action.
Compute the maximum center-to-center spacing of the piles for 100% efficiency.
Situation – Liquid Carbon Tetrachloride (CCl4) having a volume of 378 liters has a mass of 600 kg. Determine the following: The weight of Carbon Tetrachloride.
The unit weight of Carbon Tetrachloride.
The specific gravity of Carbon Tetrachloride.
Situation – A closed conical tank has a bottom radius of 25 cm and is 50 cm tall. The tank contains 0.026 m^3 of water. What is the depth of water in the tank?
What is the total volume of the tank?
How much water is required to fill the tank?

Situation – The fuel gage for a gasoline tank in a car reads proportional to its bottom gage. The tank is 35 cm deep an accidentally contaminated with 3 cm of water. Specific gravity of gasoline is 0.68. What is the gage reading when the tank is filled with gasoline?
If the tank is accidentally contaminated with 3 cm of water, how many cm of air remains on top of the tank when the gage reads "FULL"?
In part 2, if the tank has a uniform horizontal cross-sectional area of 0.45 m^2, how many liters of gasoline are required to fill the tank?

Situation – A 2.8-m square plate is immersed in water in a vertical position such that the two edges of the square are horizontal. The immersion is such that the center of pressure on the plate is 8 cm from its center of gravity. Determine the distance from the water surface to the top of the gate.
Determine the distance from the water surface to the center of pressure.
Determine the total hydrostatic force acting on one side of the gate.
Situation – A stone weighs 4 N when immersed in water and 5 N when immersed in alcohol having a specific gravity of 0.80. Unit weight of water is 9.79 kN/m^3. What is the volume of the stone?
What is the density of the stone?
What is the weight of the stone?
Situation – A piece of metal having a specific gravity of 7.5 is floating in mercury having a specific gravity of 13.6. What fraction of the total volume of the metal is above the mercury surface?
If the volume of the metal below the mercury surface is 0.018 m^3, what is the total weight of the metal?
What vertical force will keep the metal fully submerged in mercury?

Situation – A 1.5 m square tank contains water to a depth of 2.6 m. A cubical block of wood, 0.6 m on each side is made to float in water inside the tank. The specific gravity of the wood is 0.5. What is the volume of water displaced by the wood?
What is the rise in water level in the tank?
What is the change in the total force acting on the floor of the tank?

Situation – An open cylindrical tank has a base diameter of 1.2 meters contains 3.86 meters deep of water. The tank is rotated about its vertical axis at 80 rpm. What is the minimum height of the tank so that no water can be spilled at 80 rpm?
If ω = 120 rpm, how much water is spilled?
If ω = 140 rpm, what will be the pressure at the center bottom of the tank?

Situation – Two vertical tanks are connected near the bottom by a short tube having a cross sectional area of 0.00625 m^2, the cross sectional areas of the tanks are 8 m^2 and 2 m^2 respectively. The tank contains water with the water surface in the larger tank 4 m above the tube and in the smaller tank 1 m above the tube. Assume a constant discharge coefficient of 0.72. Find the flow of water to the smaller tank if the head is constant.
Find the time for the water surfaces in the two tanks to reach the same elevation.
Find the time for the water surfaces in the tanks to be 1 m apart.

Situation – Two vertical cylindrical tank, one 5 m in diameter and the other 8 m in diameter are connected by a short tube having a cross-sectional area of 0.004 m^2 with C = 0.65 located at the bottom portion. When the tube is closed, the water surface in the smaller tank is 10 m higher than that in the bigger tank. Determine the discharge in the tube immediately after it is opened.
Determine the time for the water surface in each tank to be at the same level?
Determine the time for the difference in the water surface to be 4 meters.

Situation – A weir installed at the end of a rectangular channel controls the flow of water. The rate of flow is 0.62 m^3/s. If the error the measuring head is 0.018 m, determine the error in the measured flow if: The weir is a 90-degree V-notch.
The weir is a suppressed rectangular with L = 4.5 m.
The weir is a Cipolletti with L = 4.3 m.
Situation – Water flows in a 400-mm-diameter pipe at the rate of 600 liters per second. The pipe has a length of 60 m. Compute the headloss using Darcy Weisbach formula with f = 0.028.
Compute the headloss using Hazen William's formula with C1 = 92.
Compute the headloss using Manning's formula with n = 0.013.

Situation – A turbine is installed between reservoirs A and B whose difference in water surface elevation is 140 m. The pipe connecting the reservoir has a diameter of 250 mm and is 180 m long. The flow of water is 180 L/s. Use Hazen William's Formula with C1 = 100. Determine the headloss in the pipe due to friction.
What is the head extracted by the turbine?
What is the power generated by the turbine assuming 90% efficiency?

Situation – Water flows on a straight 350 m pipe, 600 mm in diameter. The velocity of flow is 2.3 m/s. Pipe thickness is 18 mm. Bulk modulus of elasticity of water is 2.2 × 10^9 Pa. Modulus of elasticity of pipe material is 1.4 × 10^11 Pa. What is the celerity of pressure wave?
Determine the water hammer pressure assuming instantaneous closure.
Calculate the minimum time of closure to avoid the development of maximum water hammer pressure.
Situation: The beam shown in Figure 001 is part of a walkway of a gymnasium. The beam ABC can be considered simply supported at B and at C. Determine the vertical reaction at C in kN.
Determine the load carried by the column at B in kN.
Determine the maximum negative moment in the beam in kN-m.

Situation: The beam shown in Figure 002. is fixed at both ends and carries a uniformly distributed load of w = 25 kN/m throughout its length. The beam is W 16 × 77 with the following properties: bf = 260 mm, tw = 11.6 mm, tf = 19.3 mm, Ix = 462.02 × 10⁶ mm⁴, d = 420 mm, Iy = 57.44 × 10⁶ mm⁴. Calculate the maximum bending stress in the beam, in MPa.
Calculate the average shearing stress in the web, in MPa.
Calculate the maximum shearing stress in the beam, in MPa.
Situation: The tripod shown in Figure 003 supports the load W. Determine the nearest value to the maximum load W if the allowable load in each of the legs of the tripod is 10 kN.
If W = 50 kN what is the force in leg BD in kN?
If W = 50 kN what is the force in leg AD in kN?

Situation: A vertical cylindrical steel tank is 3 meters in diameter and 6 meters tall. The walls of the tank have thickness of 12 mm. What is the tangential stress in the walls when the tank is filled with water?
What is the longitudinal stress in the walls when the tank is filled with water?
How deep is the water in the tank when the maximum stress in the walls is 5 MPa?

Situation: A cantilever retaining wall, 6 meters high, has an active pressure varying uniformly from zero at the top to 52 kN/m at the bottom. The flexural rigidity of the wall is constant from top to bottom. What is the maximum shear at the base of the wall?
What is the maximum moment in the wall?
If the wall is simply supported at the top, what is the moment at the base of the wall? Use the following fixed-end moment formulas: Mtop = wL²/30, Mbase = wL²/20.

Situation: A prestressed concrete beam has a width of 300 mm and an overall depth of 600 mm. The prestressing tendons are placed at a distance “e” below the neutral axis of the beam and the applied prestressing force is P in kN. There is 15% loss of prestress. Calculate the following: What is the value of P and e when the compressive stress in the entire cross-section is 21 MPa?
What is the value of P and e when the compressive stresses at top and bottom of the beam are 2 MPa and 12 MPa, respectively?
What is the value of P and e when the compressive stresses at top and bottom of the beam are 0 MPa and 16 MPa, respectively?

Situation 7 - The column shown in Figure 004 rests on a pile cap with five piles. The piles are each 300-mm in diameter with load capacity of 320 kN. Determine the required nominal wide-beam shear strength.
Determine the required nominal punching shear strength.
Determine the required nominal moment capacity.

Situation 8 - The bolts in the lap joint shown in Figure 005 are 22 mm in diameter 25-mm-diameter holes. The plates are A36 steel with Fy = 250 MPa and Fu = 400 MPa. For this problem, x1 = 50 mm, x2 = 160 mm, x3 = 60 mm, t = 12 mm. The allowable stresses are: Bearing stress on projected area of the plates, Fp = 1.5 Fu. Tension on net area of plates, Ft = 0.5 Fu. Shear on plates, Fv = 0.3 Fo. Shear strength of bolt, Fv = 210 MPa. etermine the value of load P based on bolt shear.
Determine the value of load P based on bearing on projected area on plate.
Determine the value of load P based on block shear.

Situation 9 - The floor framing plan of a reinforced concrete slab is shown in Figure 006. It is required to determine the stirrup spacing if beam BE. The slab carries a dead load of 4.9 kPa (including its own weight) and a live load of 4.8 kPa. Unit weight of concrete is 23.5 kN/m³. Use fc = 21 MPa and fy = 275 MPa. Concrete cover is 70 mm from the centroid of tension steel area. Use 10 mm diameter vertical U-stirrup. Refer to CODE Section 5.11.1 (1992 NSCP) or Section 411.2 (2001 NSCP). What is the factored uniform load on beam BE?
What is the factored shear at critical section in beam BE?
What is the required stirrup spacing in beam BE?

Situation 10 - A 400 mm × 600 mm column with fc = 21 MPa and longitudinal steel and ties having fy = 275 MPa is subjected to factored axial forces, moments, and shears as shown in Figure 007. The factored forces and moments are as follows: Axial force, Nu = 370 kN. Positive moment, Mu = 1350 kN-m. Negative moment, Mu = 450 kN-m. See Section 5.11 of 1992 NSCP. Determine the shear strength provided by concrete using the simplified calculation given in Section 5.11.3.1.
Determine the shear strength provided by concrete using the detailed calculation given in Section 5.11.3.2.
Determine the required spacing of ties.

Situation – A load of W = 30 kN is lifted through a boom BCD as shown in the Figure. The boom makes an angle of 60° with the vertical. Neglect the weight of the boom and for this problem, L₁ = L₂ = 2 m. The pulley at D is frictionless. Determine the angle α.
What is the tension in cable AC in kN?
What is the total reaction at B in kN?
Situation – The strut shown in the Figure carries an axial load of P = 148 kN. Determine the bearing stress between the pin and strut.
Determine the shearing stress in the pin.
Determine the shearing stress in the bolts.

Situation – The column shown in the Figure is loaded with a vertical load P = 3 kN and lateral load H = 0.45 kN. The column is 3 m high and is made of steel with 300 mm outer diameter, 6 mm thick and weighs 150 N/m. What is the maximum stress at the base due to the load P?
What is the maximum stress at the base due to the lateral load?
If the column is a solid timber with diameter of 250 mm, what is the maximum shearing stress at the base?

Situation – The frame shown in the Figure is acted upon by wind load pressure of 1.44 kPa. These frames are spaced 6 m apart normal to the paper. Consider the roller support at B and the joint at D as pin. Determine the horizontal component of the reaction at A.
Determine the vertical component of the reaction at A.
Determine the horizontal component of the reaction at B.

Situation – The sheet pile shown in the Figure is provided with tension rods spaced 3 meters apart. The wooden stringers has d = 300 mm and can be considered simply supported at each connection to the tension rod. Allowable bending and shearing stresses of the stringer are 14.7 MPa and 1.48 MPa, respectively. What is the design moment of the stringer?
What is the value of stringer width b based on bending?
What is the value of stringer width b based on shear?

Situation – The 6 m long prestressed cantilever beam shown in the Figure carries a concentrated live load of 18 kN at the free end and a uniform deadload due to its own weight. Unit weight of concrete is 20 kN/m³. The strands are 12 mm in diameter with total prestressing force of 540 kN applied at an eccentricity e above the neutral axis of the gross-section. What is the maximum stress (MPa) in the bottom fiber of the beam at the free end when the eccentricity e = 0?
What is the stress in the top fiber of the beam at the fixed end when the eccentricity e = 100 mm?
What is the required eccentricity e such that the stress in the top fiber of the beam at the fixed end is zero?

Situation – Reinforced concrete beams having widths of 400 mm and overall depths of 600 mm are spaced 3 meters on centers as shown in the Figure. These beams support a 100 mm thick slab. The superimposed loads on these beams are as follows: Dead load (incl. floor finish, ceiling, etc.) = 3.2 kPa. Live load=3.6 kPa The columns E and H are omitted such that the girder BEHK supports the beams DEF at E and GHI at H. Assume EI= constan for all beams. Unit weight of concrete is 24 kN/m^3. Determine the factored uniform load on beam GHI, in kN/m
Determine the maximum factored shear (in kN) in beam GHI assuming that G and I are fixed and H is hinge.
Determine the maximum factored positive moment (in kN-m) in beam GHI assuming that G and I are fixed and H is hinge.

Situation – Channel sections are used as a purlin. The top chords of the truss are sloped at 4H to 1V. The trusses are spaced 6 m on centers and the purlins are spaced 1.2 m on centers. Loads: Dead load = 720 Pa, Live load = 1000 Pa, Wind load = 1400 Pa. Wind coefficients: Windward = +0.2, Leeward = -0.6. Properties of C200 x 76: Sx = 6.19 x 10^4 mm³, Sy = 1.38 x 10^4 mm³, Weight, w = 79 N/m, Allowable bending stresses, Fbx = Fby = 207 MPa. Determine the computed bending stress, fbx, due to combination of dead and live loads only.
Determine the computed bending stress, fby, due to combination of dead and live loads only.
Determine the value of the interaction equation using the load combination of 0.75(D + L + W) at the windward side.

Situation – The column shown in the figure is subjected to shear force parallel to the 600 mm side. Allowable concrete shear stress for shear parallel to the 600 mm side is 0.816 MPa. Concrete strength fc = 21 MPa and steel strength for both longitudinal and confining reinforcements is 415 MPa. The ties are all 12 mm in diameter with clear cover of 40 mm. Determine the factored shear force Vu that the column can resist if the nominal shear strength provided by the ties is 375 kN.
If the ties are spaced at 225 mm on centers, what is the maximum value of Vu, in kN?
If the factored shear force parallel to the 600 mm side is 400 kN, determine the required spacing of transverse reinforcement in accordance with the provisions for seismic design.

Situation – The girder AB shown in the Figure is subjected to torsional moment from the loads on the cantilever frame. The following factored forces are computed from this beam: Factored moment, Mu = 440 kN-m, Factored shear, Vu = 280 kN, Factored torque, Tu = 180 kN-m. The girder has a width of 400 mm and an overall depth of 500 mm. Concrete cover is 40 mm. The centroid of longitudinal bars of the girder are placed 65 mm from the extreme concrete fibers. Concrete strength fc = 20.7 MPa and steel yield strength for longitudinal bars is fy = 415 MPa. Use 12 mm U-stirrups with fyt = 275 MPa. Allowable shear stress in concrete is 0.76 MPa. Determine the required area of tension reinforcement of the girder, in mm².
Determine the spacing of transverse reinforcement due to Vu.
Determine the additional area of longitudinal reinforcement to resist torsion, in mm².
A vertical load of W is supported by the tripod shown. If the capacity of the each leg is 15 kN, what is the safe value of W?

Six (6) steel cables are used to support a circular moulding having a diameter of 2 m and weighing 3.6 kN/m. The cables are equally spaced around the moulding and attached to a single hook 3 m above the moulding. If the allowable stress in the cable is 105 MPa, what is the required diameter?

A vertical steel rod is fixed at the top and supports an 8-kN load at the lower end. The rod is 10 mm in diameter and 25 m long. Unit weight of steel is 77 kN/m³. What is the total elongation of the rod?

A hallow circular tube has an outside diameter of 85 mm and is 5 mm thick. The tube is fixed (cantilever) at one end and subjected to a torque of 4 kN-m at its free end. What is the maximum shearing stress in the tube?
A decorative concrete beam is simply supported over a span of 6 m. The beam weighs 4 kN/m and the cracking moment is 38 kN-m. What is the safe uniform load of the beam?

A 2.8-m cantilever beam carries a uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m throughout its length and a concentrated load of 30 kN at a point 2 meters from the fixed end. What is the bending moment at the fixed end?

A 12-m long beam is simply supported at the left end and at 3 m from the right end. The beam will be subjected to a uniformly distributed moving load. What total length of this beam must be subjected to this load to produce maximum negative moment at midspan?

Situation – The hook is subjected to three forces P, Q and S as shown. P = 35 kN and Q = 45 kN. Determine the angle α such that the resultant of the three forces is 80 kN acting horizontally to the right.
If angle α = 60°, find the magnitude of the force S such that the resultant force is horizontal to the right.
Find the magnitude of the force S such that the three forces are in equilibrium.

Situation – The horizontal distance from A at one end of the river to frame C at the other end is 20 m. The cable carries a load of W = 50 kN. The sag d of the cable is 1 m. Find the distance x₁ such that the tension in segment AB of the cable is equal to that in segment BC.
Calculate the tension in segment BC when x₁ = 5 m.
What is the total length of the cable when x₁ = 5 m?

Situation – The 1.8-m-diameter circular plate shown is supported by equally spaced posts along its circumference. A load P = 1150 kN is placed at a distance x = 0.45 m from post A. Neglecting the weight of the plate, what is the reaction at post A?
Neglecting the weight of the plate, what is the reaction at post B?
Considering the weight of the plate, what is the reaction at C? The plate is 45 mm thick and the unit weight of steel is 77 kN/m³.

Situation – A billboard 3 m high by 4 m wide is supported as shown in the Figure. The total weight of the billboard is 30 kN. H = 1.5 m, θ = 60°. Wind pressure, q = 1.6 kPa. Wind pressure coefficient, c = 1.0. The horizontal component of the reaction at A is nearest to:
What is the axial stress in strut BC whose cross-sectional dimension is 6 mm × 76 mm.
If the strut AB were replaced by a 16 mm ø steel cable, determine the normal stress (in MPa) in the cable.

Situation – A girder weighing 18 kN/m is suspended on a parabolic cable by a series of equally spaced vertical hanger. The length of the beam is 24 m and the sag of the cable is 3 m. What is the vertical component of the reaction at A?
What is the tension in the cable at the center?
If the allowable cable tension is 360 kN, what is the minimum sag?

Situation – Steel tank with an outside diameter of 600 mm has a wall thickness of 8 mm. The tank is used as storage of gas under a pressure of 2.2 MPa. Determine the value of the tangential stress in the tank wall.
Determine the value of the longitudinal stress in the tank wall.
If the allowable tensile stress in the wall is 124 MPa, to what value may the gas pressure be increased?

Situation – The solid pole shown in the figure is loaded with a vertical load P = 3 kN and lateral load H = 0.45 kN. The pole is 3 m high, 280 mm diameter and weighs 22 kN/m^3. What is the maximum compressive stress at the base?
What is the maximum tensile stress at the base?
What is the maximum shearing stress in the pole?

Situation – The barge shown in the figure supports the load w1 and w2. For this problem, w1 = 145 kN/m, w2 = 290 kN/m, L1 = 3 m, L2 = 6 m, L3 = 3 m. What is the length of the barge "L" so that the upward pressure is uniform.
What is the shear at 3 m from the left end?
At what distance from the left end will the shear in the barge be zero.

Situation – A concrete pad supports two load distributed loads of 112 kN/m as shown in the figure. It required to determine the maximum shear and moment in the pad due to these loads. What uniform base pressure "q" is induced by these loads?
What is the maximum shear acting on the concrete pad?
What is the maximum moment on the pad?

Situation – A 10-m long beam is simply supported at the left end and at 2 m from the right end. The beam will be analyzed for maximum shear at the midspan that can be induced by a moving load. What is the ordinate of the influence diagram at the midspan?
What is the ordinate of the influence diagram at the free end?
The beam will be subjected to a uniformly distributed moving load. What total length of this beam must be subjected to this load to produce maximum shear at the midspan?

Situation – The trussed beam shown is 5.4 m long. A man of weight "W" is standing at the middle of the beam. Neglect the weight of the beam. If the capacity of the rod is 2 kN, what is the safe maximum weight of the man in kg?
If the man weighs 85 kg, what is the tensile stress in the rod if its diameter is 10 mm?
What is the total length of the rod?
Situation – The truss shown in is made from Guijo 100 mm × 150 mm. The load on the truss is 20 kN. Neglect friction. Determine the minimum value of x.
Determine the minimum value of y in mm.
What is the axial stress on member AC in MPa?

Situation – The lap joint of a tension member is shown in the figure. The plate 252 mm wide and 12 mm thick. The bolts are 20 mm in diameter and the holes are 3 mm larger than the bolt diameter. Steel is A36 with Fy = 248 MPa and Fu = 400 MPa. It is required to determine the capacity of the joint based on gross area, net area, and block shear. Determine the safe value of P based on tension on gross area.
Determine the safe value of P based on tension on net area.
Determine the safe value of P based on tension on block shear.
Situation – A 6-m long fixed-ended beam carries a uniformly distributed load of 20 kN/m. Use E = 200 GPa and Ix = 67.5 x 10^6 mm^4. Determine the moment at the fixed end.
What is the maximum shear in the beam?
Compute the vertical deflection at the midspan.
Situation – A fixed ended beam has a span of 10 m and supports a super imposed uniformly distributed load of 20 kN/m. Calculate the maximum bending stress in the beam.
What is the average shearing stress in the beam?
Determine the maximum shearing stress in the beam.

Situation – A built-up section consisting of W350 × 90 with two 12-mm plates welded to form a box section as shown in Figure S01. The section is used as a column 10 meters long. The column is fixed at both ends, and braced at midheight about the weak axis (Y-axis). The code provision is given in Figure NSCP-01. Use Fy = 248 MPa. Determine the effective slenderness ratio of the column with respect to lateral buckling about the x-axis.
Determine the effective slenderness ratio of the column with respect to lateral buckling about the y-axis.
Determine the axial load capacity of the column in kN.

Situation – A box column is formed by welding two channel sections at the top of their flanges. The column has an unsupported length of 4 m and is hinged at both ends (K = 1.0). What is the compressive stress in the column due to an axial compressive load of 900 kN?
What is the maximum bending stress in the column due to a moment of 70 kN-m about the x-axis of the section?
What is the critical (maximum) effective slenderness ratio of the column?

Situation – The deck of a bridge consist of ribbed metal deck with 100 mm concrete slab on top. The superstructure supporting the deck is made of wide flange steel beams strengthened by cover plate 16 mm × 260 mm one at the top and one at the bottom, and is spaced 1.2 m on centers. The beams are simply supported over a span of 25 m. The loads on each beam are as follows: Dead load = 12 kN/m (including beam weight and deck), Wheel live loads: Front wheel = 18 kN, Rear wheel = 72 kN, Wheel base = 4.3 m, Impact factor = 15/(L+37) ≤ 30%, where L = length in m. Calculate the maximum bending stress in the beam due to dead load.
Calculate the maximum bending stress in the beam due to live load plus impact.
Calculate the maximum average web shear stress in the beam due to live load plus impact.

Situation – The W450 × 86 beam is supported by a concrete wall and a 130-mm-wide bearing plate as shown. The beam reaction is 250 kN. All steel are A36 steel with Fy = 248 MPa. Concrete strength fc' = 27.5 MPa. What is the required width of bearing plate "W"?
Using the width in Part 1, what is the required plate thickness. Assume that the critical section in bending for bearing plate is at distance "k" from the axis of the beam.
Determine the web yielding stress at the web toe of fillet.

Situation – The floor framing plan of a reinforced concrete structure is shown in the figure. The beams are 280 mm wide and 520 mm deep and the slab is 110 mm thick. Other than concrete weight, the floor is subjected to an additional (superimposed) dead load of 3 kPa and live load of 5.2 kPa. Unit weight of concrete is 23.5 kN/m^3. Due to space consideration, the columns at E and H are to be removed. This will make girder BEHK support the beams DEF at E and GHI at H. Use the tributary area method. Determine the uniform service dead load on beam DEF.
Determine the uniform service live load on beam DEF.
Determine the factored concentrated load at F due to loads on beam DEF.

Situation – The floor framing plan of a reinforced concrete structure is shown in the figure. When columns E and H are deleted, girder BEHK carries the reaction of BEF at E and GIK at H. This girder may be considered fixed at B and K. The uniform load on this girder is 5 kN/m and the concentrated loads at E and H are each 270 kN. Calculate the maximum shear at B due to uniform and concentrated loads.
Calculate the maximum shear at E due to concentrated load only.
Calculate the maximum positive moment in the girder due to uniform load only.

Situation – The rectangular footing shown is subjected to an axial load of P = 1200 kN and a moment of M = 360 kN-m. It is required to determine the safe gross bearing capacity of the soil to support the given loads. The unit weights of concrete and soil are 23.5 kN/m^3 and 18 kN/m^3 respectively. What is the maximum foundation pressure in kPa?
What is the minimum foundation pressure in kPa?
What is the minimum required gross allowable soil bearing capacity to carry the given loads?

Situation – The T-beam shown resulted from monolithic construction of the beam and slab. The effective flange width is 1100 mm and the uniform slab thickness is 120 mm. Width of beam is 340 mm, total depth of the T-section is 590 mm. The centroid of steel is 70 mm from extreme concrete fiber. Concrete strength fc' = 21 MPa and steel strength fy = 415 MPa. Use the strength design method. Calculate the nominal strength of the beam for positive moment neglecting the contribution of the top reinforcement.
Calculate the nominal strength of the beam for negative moment.
Calculate the required nominal shear strength of the beam if it is subjected to a factored shear of 220 kN.

Situation – A reinforced concrete beam has a width of 300 mm and an overall depth of 480 mm. The beam is simply supported over a span of 5 m. Steel strength fy = 415 MPa and concrete strength fc' = 28 MPa. Concrete cover is 70 mm from the centroid of the steel area. Unit weight of concrete is 23.5 kN/m^3. Other than the weight of the beam, the beam carries a superimposed dead load of 18 kN/m and a live load of 14 kN/m. Use the strength design method. Determine the maximum factored moment on the beam.
If the design ultimate moment capacity of the beam is 280 kN-m, determine the required number of 20 mm tension bars.
If the beam will carry an additional factored load of 240 kN at midspan, determine the required number of 20 mm tension bars.

Situation – The section of a column is shown in the figure. For this problem, b1 = 300 mm, b2 = 180 mm, d1 = 250 mm, d2 = 350 mm, fc' = 28 MPa, fy = 414 MPa. Determine the location of the centroid of the gross concrete area measured from y-axis.
Determine the location of the plastic neutral axis of the column measured from the y-axis. Neglect the area of concrete occupied by the steel.
Determine the factored moment Mu due to a factored load Pu = 3200 kN applied 400 mm from the y-axis. Assume that the column is reinforced such that the plastic neutral axis is 290 mm from the y-axis.

Situation – The column shown in the figure is subjected to shear force parallel to the 600 mm side. Allowable concrete shear stress for shear parallel to the 600 mm side is 0.816 MPa. Concrete strength fc' = 21 MPa and steel strength for both longitudinal and confining reinforcements is 415 MPa. The ties are all 12 mm in diameter with clear cover of 40 mm. Determine the factored shear force Vu that the column can resist if the nominal shear strength provided by the ties is 375 kN.
If the ties are spaced at 230 mm on centers, what is the maximum value of Vu in kN?
If the factored shear force parallel to the 600 mm side is 400 kN, determine the required spacing of transverse reinforcement in accordance with the provisions for seismic design.

Situation – A prestressed concrete beam has a width of 300 mm and an overall depth of 600 mm. The prestressing tendons are placed at a distance "e" below the neutral axis of the beam and the applied prestressing force is P = 1500 kN. There is 15% loss of prestress. Determine the compressive stress in concrete when P is applied at the centroid of the beam.
What is the maximum compressive stress in the beam when e = 120 mm
Determine the value of the eccentricity "e" such that the resulting stress at the top fiber of the beam is zero.

Situation – The section of a prestressed double-tee concrete floor joist is shown in the figure. The prestressing force in each tee is 750 kN. Unit weight of concrete is 23.5 kN/m^3. The properties of the double-tee section are: Area = 220,000 mm^2, I = 1890 × 10^6 mm^4, yb = 90 mm, yt = 270 mm, y1 = 75 mm. Simple span, L = 8 m. Service loads on floor: Dead load = 2.5 kPa, Live load = 6 kPa. Determine the initial stress at the bottom fibers due to prestressing force alone.
Determine the stress at the bottom fibers due to service load and prestressing force. Assume that there is a loss of prestress of 20% at service loads.
Calculate the additional load the floor can carry so that the stress at the bottom fibers at the midspan is zero.

Situation – A square footing is shown in the figure. The footing is to support a 400 mm × 400 mm column that carried an axial dead load of 740 kN and an axial live load of 460 kN. Use fc' = 20.7 MPa and fy = 275 MPa. Main bar diameter = 20 mm, concrete cover from centroid of main bars = 90 mm. Calculate the factored shear on footing at critical section for wide-beam action.
Calculate the factored shear on footing at critical section for two-way action.
Determine the required number of 20-mm bars.
Situation – Answer the following questions: Which of the following deals with forces at rest?
Which of the following forces determines whether a body will be at rest or in motion.
Energy by virtue of velocity.
Situation – Answer the following questions on axial deformation of rigid bodies: Within proportional limit, the stress is directly proportional to strain.
The ratio of lateral strain to longitudinal strain.
Within elastic range, the slope of the straight line portion of the stress-strain curve.
